Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man wearing a nasty metal helmet staggers past a sign warning 'it is forbidden to dump bodies into the river'. He wrenches a metal collar off with a cry and walks down the steps into the water, where he drowns. Then the Tardis materialises.
The scanner is not working.

Dialogue.Line: It's not clear. It's not clear at all. What has gone wrong?
Well, Doctor, where are we now, then.
Somewhere nice and quiet, I hope.
Oh, yes. Let's have a holiday.
Take a look for yourselves.
Well, I can't see anything.
Neither can I.
Well, it looks like moving water to me. It might be a river somewhere. I don't know. What's the reading, Susan?
Radiation nil, oxygen normal, pressure normal. Grandfather, it's an Earth reading.
Well, I don't want to boast, but we might be somewhere in London, hmm?
Well, what are we waiting for? Let's go and have a look.
Come on, open the doors.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The warehouse and embankment along the river is definitely London

Dialogue.Line: Barbara, we made it. We're here!
Well, there we are. Back home. Your planet.
You brought us a long way round, Doctor.
More by good luck than judgment. What a horrible mess.
Are we down by the docks?
(shouts) Hello! Pretty deserted. Probably Sunday.
It's uncanny. Wonder which era we've landed in?
What was that, Doctor?
Oh, I'm just wondering about the time factor, my boy.
Oh, a year or two either way doesn't make much difference to us, you know.
Well I hope for both your sakes we're near your time, but bear in mind we might have landed in the early 1900s or the 25th century.
Well, it's still London, anyway.
Yes. Hey, what are you doing?
I'm just having a look. Can't see much down there, can you.
Yes, that's the word I was looking for, decay. It's most odd, most odd.
Doctor, what's worrying you?
Well, you take this bridge, now. It isn't an easy task, is it? Look at all this neglect all over the place. It's been abandoned, all of it.
There's always a mess with construction work, Doctor.
Perhaps, perhaps.
Oh, come on, Doctor. Stop spoiling everything.
Oh my dear, now believe you me, I wouldn't spoil your homecoming for all the world.
(at the top of the wall) Still can't see much. There's not a sign of any people anywhere.
Be careful, my child.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: too late, she falls

Dialogue.Line: Susan.
I think she's just shaken.
Yes, you're always dashing about, aren't you. You're far too curious.
You're lucky it wasn't any worse.
My ankle.
Look out, this whole thing's going to go!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: they carry Susan away just as the bridge collapses onto the Tardis

Dialogue.Line: The ship, Chesterton. The ship! Don't go to near, my boy, its not safe.
The whole bridge has collapsed.
Yes, well, it's all crumbling.
We're going to need help to shift this.
Yes, it's going to be very difficult, but remember we're in London.
What's that got to do with it?
Well, the people, they'll all be curious. They'll want to know why we're trying to break into a police box.
Yes. If they don't ask what a police box is doing under a bridge in the first place.
Yes, exactly.
You know, it's primarily this girder. What I need is an acetylene torch.
Oh, my dear boy, you can't just whisk up men and material out of the thin air now, can you, hmm?
There's a warehouse over there, Doctor. I might be able to find a crowbar or something.
You know, my dear boy, I never fail to be impressed by your optimism. You can't move that by sheer brute force. You were right, you need a cutting flame.
I know one thing for sure, Doctor. We'd better make sure we can get back into the ship before we start looking around, just in case there's trouble.
It's intelligent. That's good. But you know, young man, I have a feeling, or call it intuition if you like. I don't believe we're anywhere near your time, the 1960's.
I hope it is only an intuition, Doctor.
Yes, well, ask yourself. Here we are, standing by the Thames and we've been here quite a while, how long? Quarter of an hour, twenty minute?
Easily, but what about it?
Well, what have we heard? Nothing. Precisely nothing. No sound of birdsong, no voices, no sound of shipping, and not even the chimes of old Big Ben. It's uncanny. Uncanny.
I'm lucky, aren't I?
There are no bones broken, anyway.
Thank goodness. I'm sorry about what happened, Grandfather.
Oh, so you're sitting up and taking notice again, are you?
Don't be angry with me, there's no real harm done was there? I just twisted my ankle.
No, no harm done, child. No harm done, no. Do you realise we can't get into the ship? What's all this rubble then? Look at it.
I didn't pull the bridge down on purpose.
The Doctor and I are going to have a look in that warehouse over there.
Well, can't we all go?
Well, how's your ankle, Susan?
I'll try it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: but she can't put her weight on it

Dialogue.Line: It's not very good, is it. It's awfully swollen.
Well, that settles it then. You need to stay here.
We shall be as quick as we can. And you bathe that ankle. What you need is a jolly good smacked bottom! Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian and the Doctor leave

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Susan, it is swollen. Can you twiddle your toes?
Yes. That's all right.
You wait here then. I'll go and wet my handkerchief in the river.
I'm sorry, Barbara.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Crane chains creak in the breeze. It looks very like old Wapping to me. The Doctor and Ian go up an iron staircase

Dialogue.Line: Let's take a snoop.
Careful, Doctor.
I'm not a half-wit.
Hello, there!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara reads the notice, and worries

Dialogue.Line: You know, we're not in our time in London, Susan.
Why do you say that?
Well, I know London, and it isn't like this. The river's too quiet and there's no sound of traffic. There's a strange poster on the wall back there. It just doesn't make sense.
Well, off we go again. I'm sorry, Barbara. Is it selfish to want us all to stay together?
No, of course not. We ought to be able to hear something. It's ridiculous.
Things have to stay as they are, don't they. Can't change.
I suppose so. Anyway, maybe they've done away with noise altogether. How's your ankle feeling?
It's throbbing crazy.
I don't think this is wet enough. Hold on a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: they're being watched

Dialogue.Line: Chesterton, come here.
Empty.
What a musty smell. This place hasn't been used in years.
(looking out of the window) Doctor, it's lost two chimneys.
What's that monstrosity out there?
It's Battersea Power Station. I wonder what's happened to those two chimneys?
What's happened to London, dear boy, is more to the point.
They must have gone over to nuclear power.
What's this, then?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: the Doctor finds a calendar in a desk drawer

Dialogue.Line: Ah, here, look. At least we know the century, dear boy. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara is soaking her handkerchief again when she sees the body of the suicide float past. She goes back to

Dialogue.Line: Susan? Susan!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There's the sound of gunfire, and a man jumps down from the wall

Dialogue.Line: Who are you? Do you want to get killed?
Where's Susan? What have you done with her? You mean the girl? Tyler's got her. Come on, we've got to get out of here. Quick, follow me!
Wait!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian looks up at the sound of gunfire

Dialogue.Line: There's so much rubbish. It's a jungle here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: he knocks over a cardboard box, and a man wearing a metal helmet falls out

Dialogue.Line: What the? He's dead. What on earth is this?
It looks like some sort of adornment, but what for?
I don't know. Do you think it could be some sort of medical aid? You know, if he'd fractured his skull, something to knit the bones together?
No, I think there's something more to it than that. You know, I think that this is an extra ear, ideal for picking up high-frequency radio waves.
You mean these people have invented some form of personal communication?
Yes, something like that.
What's this? A whip. Why.
Well, whatever it is, I wouldn't like to meet one of these fellows, you know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: something creaks, they stand and then see the knife in the back of the dead man

Dialogue.Line: He was murdered!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go looking for the source of the creaking. Ian kicks down a door

Dialogue.Line: Storeroom. That noise came from up here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He kicks in another door, and falls outside. Ian manages to grab hold of an iron framework. The Doctor helps him back up and in

Dialogue.Line: Right, dear boy, come on.
No one can get through that way.
Except you. I think we'd better pause in this search and get back to the others. Come along.
All right, you lead on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara follows the man through the overgrown White City Underground station while Tyler gently carries Susan down the steps. Meanwhile, Ian and the Doctor observe a flying saucer
Barbara knocks into an oil drum as she catches up with Tyler and Susan

Dialogue.Line: Careful, Barbara.
Quickly, now.
What about Grandfather and my other friend?
We'll do the best we can.
That's not what you said just now!
Look, you promised you'd find a way
There isn't time to argue. We'll collect your friends later. Now, come on.
Barbara? Susan? Why? Why do they do it?
It might have been something to do with that gunfire we heard across the river.
Yes, I suppose they might have hidden somewhere.
Well, let's wait and see, hmm?
That body. You know, I want to get away from here.
Yes, but aren't you even a bit curious? After all, it's your city, you know. Don't you want to know what's happened to it?
No. No, I don't want to know. Where the devil are those two?
Hold on.
Is this is?
Yes. (he puts Susan down) Now get back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He presses on a metal panel, a duct moves back

Dialogue.Line: Tyler?
Yes.
Dortmun's on the rampage. And who have we got here?
I found a couple of them down by the river. Open targets.
Well, we didn't know.
I suppose you didn't, but you know now.
Can you cook?
Yes, I can get by.
Good, we need some cooks.
Listen, I
All right, let's get down.
Listen, I had a struggle with one of the Robomen.
Well?
Well, he was waiting for me! That means that we'll have to change the storehouse.
All right, tell Dortmun. Have you just come from there?
Yes.
These have got a couple of friends down there they want us to bring back.
Well I didn't see anyone there except that I was nearly caught by a couple... They didn't go into the old warehouse, did they, that's opposite the old power station?
Yes, I think they did.
Yeah, and I thought they were enemies.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: a man in a wheelchair enters

Dialogue.Line: Tyler, where have you been? What the devil have you been doing?
They've landed a saucer at the heliport.
Saucer?
Yes.
Ah, this time we'll be ready for them.
You shouldn't be up here.
I'm as active as anybody else.
All right, Dortmun, I know.
Two more pairs of hands. Good, we need
She says she can cook.
Oh, can you?
And what do you do?
I eat.
Look, I'll try and find the two friends and bring them back here.
Thank you.
David, where are you going?
Well, there's two more of them down by the warehouse.
Men, are they?
Yes.
Good. Don't be too long away. I'm going through the attack plans with Tyler as soon as possible. I want you to be there.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: David leaves

Dialogue.Line: What attack plans?
Why are you sitting down?
I've hurt my ankle. What attack plans?
Come along, Tyler, get these people below. That's the way. I'll stay here, on watch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tyler carries Susan, and Dortmun closes the duct

Dialogue.Line: High tide.
Hmm?
High tide.
Evening. Look how filthy that water is.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian sees the poster

Dialogue.Line: Doctor. Doctor, come and have a look at this.
Hmm? What?
Look.
Huh, stupid.
Read it, read it.
Well, I repeat, it's stupid. A stupid place to put a poster. Right under a bridge where nobody can read it or see it.
I don't know. If you have a body to get rid of, I should think it's a very good place to come to.
A dead human body in the river? I should say that's near murder, isn't it, hmm?
Bring out your dead.
Hmm?
Plague?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: looking out of a window

Dialogue.Line: There they are. That must be them. Argh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two men in a metal helmets are patrolling the warehouse dock frontage. They move slowly and stiffly like automata

Dialogue.Line: Why have the human beings been allowed to get so near the river?
Doctor, that voice.
No explanation.
Where is the Robo-control for this section?
Not known.
You will take his place until he is found. The human beings are to be taken to landing area one.
Daleks on Earth! Doctor, how did this happen?
Leave this to me, dear boy. I think you'd better let us go.
We do not release prisoners. We are the masters of the Earth.
Not for long.
Obey us or die.
Die? And just who are you to condemn us to death? (sotto) I think we'd better pit our wits against them and defeat them.
Stop. I can hear you. I have heard many similar words from leaders of your different races. All of them were destroyed. I warn you, resistance is useless.
Resistance is useless? Surely you don't expect all the people to welcome you with open arms?
We have already conquered Earth.
Conquered the Earth? You poor, pathetic creatures. Don't you realise? Before you attempt to conquer the Earth, you will have to destroy all living matter.
Take them. Take them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian and the Doctor are manhandled away

Dialogue.Line: We are the masters of Earth. We are the masters of Earth. We are the masters of Earth.
Survivors of London, the Daleks are the masters of Earth. Surrender now and you will live. Those wishing to surrender must stand in the middle of the street, and obey orders received. Message ends.
Obey motorised dustbins? We'll see. Tyler, I want a word with you.
Jenny, see if you can find them some food, will you, and look after her ankle.
All right.
You'll keep your eyes open for David Campbell. He'll be back soon with news of your friends.
Any messages from any other survivors?
No. The Africa group have faded out completely.
Who's the one with the bad foot?
Me.
Well, let's have a look then.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She takes Susan's shoe off and flexes her foot

Dialogue.Line: Ow!
Hmm. There are no bones broken. Why didn't you put a wet bandage on it?
We've only just arrived.
I see. Well, I'll see to this. You get the food. What are you waiting for?
Well, where do I get the food?
Oh, over there. And while you're at it, sign both your names down for a work detail.
Susan can't work until her ankle's better.
She can do something with her hands, sitting at a table, can't she?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The two men are looking at maps

Dialogue.Line: But look, look there. We must attack them, Tyler.
That sounds fine, but how? We can find fifteen, perhaps twenty men.
Ample.
Oh what are you talking about, ample. A handful of unarmed men against Daleks?
Sometimes I wonder about you, Tyler.
This isn't the 20th century. Dortmun, when thousands of men with bayonets charged machine guns.
Don't lecture me.
Then don't ask the impossible. You've not been out there for ages. It would be suicide.
Oh, yes, all right, I know. I'm in this wheelchair so I can't go myself.
I didn't mean that. You know I didn't mean that. The new bomb?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A classic round design with a fuse out of the top

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it's finished.
You haven't had it tested, I suppose?
Tested? Don't be a fool, it doesn't need testing. It's all there in my formula. It's perfect. I tell you, this bomb will destroy the Daleks. I know it will work.
Apples. There are apples there for everyone. Jenny, you should be filling three of these.
You've been down here so long that you're beginning to think like worms.
We must have some chance of success.
Campbell reporting in.
Good. Tyler and I have been having a preliminary chat about the next attack. We'll be out soon.
Well I've brought a box of apples. Incidentally, that department store's got plenty of stuff in it.
Oh, right.
And what about the two men?
When I got down to the embankment I saw them being taken away, but I couldn't do anything.
Oh, that's bad, that's very bad. We could have done with those two men.
I'll tell the two women.
Where were the men taken? Any idea?
From the direction they went, I think the Daleks have taken them the saucer they landed at the heliport in Chelsea.
Doctor, I don't understand this at all. We saw the Daleks destroyed on Skaro. We were there.
My dear boy, what in Skaro was a million years ahead of us in the future. What we're seeing now is about the middle history of the Daleks.
I see. They certainly look different, don't they.
Look, they've taken some more prisoners. What is so different about the Daleks? Oh, I see. You mean the discs on their backs.
Yes. Perhaps that accounts for their increased mobility. Do you remember, on Skaro they could only move on metal.
Yes, yes, quite so. But remember, this is an invasion force, therefore they have to adapt themselves to the planet.
Where are the other two from your patrol?
This man killed them both.
For this you will be punished. Continue your patrol. The prisoners will fall in line.
There'll be no escape once they get us inside there.
They're not getting me. I'm going to try something. You with me?
Don't be a fool mate, you haven't got a chance.
They're not getting me back in that filthy mine.
The prisoners will remain silent.
Forward.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the humans are herded up the ramp, the young man tries to break away, but a Dalek gets in his way. He circles round, and the Daleks gather. One has a black top and black side panels - and a very high-pitched voice

Dialogue.Line: Don't be a fool. You can't help him now.
Help me!
Kill him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: So they do

Dialogue.Line: Any further resistance will be dealt with in the same way.
The prisoners will proceed into the ship.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan hold the rifle steady while David cleans it

Dialogue.Line: No, Susan, I don't think we should tell Barbara.
But David, I think we should.
Now listen, Susan. We're going to make an attack on that saucer, so we'll put off telling her until afterwards.
You mean if the attack's successful, we'll find Ian and my grandfather anyway.
Yes. And if it isn't, well then, they've just disappeared.
All right.
You wanted to see these.
Oh, yes.
Well here you are then, take them. I've got better things to do.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Hands over Robo-helmets

Dialogue.Line: Oh, you're a model of charm and patience, aren't you.
Well, I don't believe in wasting time and I don't believe in sentiment either.
(with apples) They asked me to give these out, Jenny.
Oh, just put it down there.
Dessert.
Thank you.
Thank you, Barbara.
Oh, what are these things?
Oh they're the Dalek's invention. They're called Robomen.
No, Susan, I told you. You've got it wrong. We took these from dead human beings.
There aren't that many Daleks on Earth. They needed helpers so they operated on some of their prisoners and turned them into robots.
I see.
The transfer, as the Daleks call the operation, controls the human brain, well at least for a time.
What happens then?
Do they revert and become human again?
No. They die.
I've seen the Robos when they break down. They go insane. They smash their heads against walls, they throw themselves off buildings or into the river.
The river? That's what it was. Daleks. Everything they touch turns into a horrible sort of nightmare.
Are they still doing these transfer operations, David?

Oh, yes. They keep up their numbers of Robomen. They got my brother last year. That's another reason why they saucers at the heliport. That's where the Daleks take the prisoners and operate on them. Once they've got you on board a saucer, there isn't a hope.
Yes, the work of a genius, dear boy.
Yes, pretty impressive. And absolutely escape-proof.
Only on the surface, my friends.
Move.
Halt. You will move one by one slowly into the prison cell.
Move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor goes another way

Dialogue.Line: You. Reverse and move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor rejoins Ian and the man and they get locked in

Dialogue.Line: Is that the one?
Yes. He spoke of resistance.
His words betray greater intelligence than normal in human beings.
Give them the test.
I had a good look into that corridor. Did you notice the television eyes round about?
Yes, I did. There aren't any in here.
No.
I'll tell you what I did see, Doctor. What I took to be a loading bay door. Of course, it could be guarded outside.
It will be.
Yes. Nevertheless, it has possibilities.
What for? You can't get the door open. There's no escape, I tell you.
My young friend, don't be so pessimistic. What is your name, by the way?
Craddock, Jack Craddock.
Well, Mister Jack Craddock, don't be such a defeatist. Our job is to try and get out of here, and quickly.
You're just fooling yourselves. You don't know the Daleks. Once they've got you inside a saucer, you're finished.
Craddock, tell us, how did it happen, the invasion of Earth? Everything.
Have you been on a moon station or something?
Yes, quite so.
Yes.

Well, meteorites came first. The Earth was bombarded with them about ten years ago. A cosmic storm, the scientists called it. The meteorites stopped, everything settled down, and then people began to die of this new kind of plague.
Yes, that explains your poster, dear boy. Germ bombs, hmm?

Yes. The Daleks were up in the sky just waiting for Earth to get weaker. Whole continents of people were wiped out. Asia, Africa, South America. They used to say the Earth had a smell of death about it.
Why, Craddock? What were the doctors and the scientists doing about it?
Oh, well, they came up with some new kind of drug but it was too late then.
Why?
What happened next?
Well, the plague had split the world into tiny little communities, too far apart to combine and fight, and too small individually to stand any chance against invasion.
Divide and conquer.

Hmm. About six months after the meteorite fall, that's when the saucers landed. Cities were razed to the ground, others were simply occupied. Anyone who resisted was destroyed. Some people were captured and were turned into Robomen, the slaves of the Daleks. They caught other human beings and many of them were shipped to the vast mining areas. No one escapes. The Robomen see to that.
They were our own people, made to work against us, and the Daleks knew that, knew how they'd humiliated and degraded us. They are the masters of Earth.
But why, Craddock? That's the one thing you haven't told us. What is it that the Daleks want on Earth?
I don't know. Something under the ground. They've turned the whole of Bedfordshire into a gigantic mine area.
Why? What are they digging for?
I don't know.
Suppose we forget all this blab about Bedfordshire. Have either of you seen this?
All radio waves bands are open.

Rebels of London, this is our last offer. Our final warning. Leave your hiding places. Show yourselves in the open streets. You will be fed and watered. Work is needed from you but the Daleks offer you life.
Rebel against us and the Daleks will destroy London completely. You will all die, the males, the females and descendants. Rebels of London, come out of your hiding places. The Daleks offer you life.
Come out of your hiding places. We'll come out of our hiding place with this! (the bomb) This bomb will shatter the casing of the Daleks. We don't need to run or hide any more. We'll make them run.
At last we've got a weapon.
He's done it.
Listen carefully. They've issued an ultimatum. We'll give our answer tonight. Tyler and I both agree that the best place for an attack is the heliport where they land the flying saucers.
A frontal attack?
Yes, a frontal attack.
Of course, we have the superior weapon now. One success will give our people hope again. One victory will set this country, the whole of Europe, alight. That's all we need, one victory.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Cheers

Dialogue.Line: At the heliport, how do we get within throwing range?
The heliport's fringed with buildings. We're covered right up to the perimeter.
The Daleks can fire at us long before we can use the bomb.
It'll be a surprise attack.
As soon as the first bomb is thrown, surprise is over and we shall be penned in the buildings, remember.
All right, Baker, we know we'll have to get closer.
I know.
Who was that? Well?
We could get right into the middle of the Daleks without them suspecting anything if we use this.
How?
Some of your men could disguise themselves as Robomen. They could pretend to be escorting a batch of prisoners to the saucer, or something.
It'll work.
Yes, it'll work. We'll attack the saucer in one hour from now.
What is that you've got there?
A magnifying glass. I just picked it up.
Hey, Doctor, come and look at this. Look. What do you make of this?
I wouldn't touch it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It is a block of perspex with seven vertical tubes cut into it and a piece of metal in the middle

Dialogue.Line: Hmm. Let me have that bar up there for a moment, will you?
Is it glass or something?
I should say it was more advanced than that. Well now, let's try a little experiment.
All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the Doctor holds the bar above the block, the metal piece inside moves along

Dialogue.Line: Hey!
You see? It responds. Magnetised.
A profound discover, mister. Doesn't help us.
Why did the Daleks put it there in the first place?
Now that's a very good question, dear boy. Suppose you were a Dalek and you found yourself locked up in this room. How would you get out?
Push the door open?
My dear young man, the Daleks have only feelers, no hands, and they use their brains, not brute force.
You mean this is some sort of a key?
Now that's the very word. A key in a crystal box. You open the box, take out the key and use it. That is precisely what the Dalek would do.
Yes, but what are we going to do, Doctor?
Look at that little light up there.
Yes, I see. And the box is transparent.
Quite. Let me have that thing, will you?
What, this?
Yes, that. Thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: He holds the magnifying glass above the box

Dialogue.Line: Now, we have to make sure that we hit the correct refractive, otherwise we shall get showered with crystal glass.
Refractive rubbish! The Daleks don't leave things like this about for you to help yourselves.

My dear boy, if they had to deal with a man of your talents, they need hardly fear, need they. Now do sit down and rest, please. Oh, dear, now where were we? Ah, yes, of course, yes, yes, yes. Now, X equals gamma, that means roughly two and a half percent, so that should give us a curve of around about eighty degrees. Oh by the way, did you take three dimensional graph geometry at your school, hmm?
No, Doctor, only Boyle's Law.

What a pity. What a pity. We shall have to boil this down now, shan't we. Well, now then, let's see. We'll start third from the left and then I'll follow it from the right and straight over. All right? Now put that bar there, and watch your eyes because you know, it might be nasty. Are you ready?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian holds the metal bar at the end of the box, where there is a hole

Dialogue.Line: And a great big pumpkin too.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Then the metal shoots out of the box

Dialogue.Line: Hey, look at that.
Hold that and shut up, will you. Pay attention. Let me have the bar, please.
You know, Doctor, sometimes you astound me.
Only sometimes, dear boy? What's happened to your memory? Don't you remember we know that the Daleks can use static electricity?
Of course.
Hey, how do you know so much about them, the Daleks I mean.
We met them once before.

Yes, and we happened to outwit them, too. Please go away, will you? Oh, dear, dear, dear, dear. Now, all we have to do is to slide this bar back here, and the self-same bar slides back into place here through electricity.
And it's held in place by magnetic force.
Precisely. Now I want you to give him a hand in a minute. Just turn that pole under there, will you. There, you see?
I see what you mean. Like poles repel, eh?
Yes, precisely. Now we've created a force field. Right, now turn the pole round. Give him a hand, quickly. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It takes both men to handle the metal bar now

Dialogue.Line: Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And the cell door opens

Dialogue.Line: You're a genius.
Yes, there are very few of us left. Now, let's get out, and be crafty.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They are immediately surrounded by Daleks and Robomen

A Slyther? What's that?
Where do you come from, mate? Fairyland?
The Black Dalek, he's the commandant of the camp, regards it as a sort of pet.
You mean it's on some sort of a guard duty?
Yes, well, in a way. Mainly it roams the mine area at night in search of food.
What sort of food?
People.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: At the bottom of a ladder

Dialogue.Line: Tyler!
He can't have got so far ahead.
Perhaps our voices aren't carrying. These walls could deflect the sound, I suppose.
There's a ladder there.
Yes.
Let's try up there.
Yes, all right. (goes up the steps) There's a tunnel through here.
Careful, Susan.
I'm all right. Tyler? (comes to an edge with a ladder down) Tyler? Are you down there?
Careful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As she starts to go down the ladder, it comes away from the wall at the top and she is left hanging onto a rung

Dialogue.Line: David! (scream) David!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Below her, an alligator lines up in the hope its next meal is about to drop in, then a manhole cover opens above and a shot rings out. Tyler and David pull the ladder back to the wall and help Susan up

Dialogue.Line: Steady. Are you all right?
Yes. Swinging.
You'd have probably given him indigestion anyway.
Thank you.
All right now, come on. I've found the Doctor. He's waiting for us up here.
Okay, now take your time.
Where's Grandfather's stick?
I'll bring it. Take your time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ashton uses a jewellers eye-piece to check his payment as the others eat

Dialogue.Line: You know, Wells, you're a fool. For all this stuff I'd have gladly taken you outside. There are plenty of small towns and villages that the Daleks have cleared of people and left intact. Food galore.
I'll get out in my own good time.
Well, suit yourself. You people never learn, do you.
(hands something to Wells) That's for the two of us. Thanks for ours.
Right, I'll take it, if you don't mind. It'll help pay for the next lot from Ashton.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Slyther roars, then there's a sound like a big heart beat. Suddenly, Slyther has managed to get into the Earth Mover. Ashton shoots at it

Dialogue.Line: Get out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry slips at the edge

Dialogue.Line: Larry!
Ian!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry grabs the edge of a mining bucket. Ian leaps into the bucket itself

Dialogue.Line: Hold on, Larry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: IAN hauls Larry up into the bucket.

Dialogue.Line: All right?
Thanks.
It's still coming. I hope it can't jump.
It's going to try!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Slyther grabs the edge of the bucket, so Ian grabs a rock and hits it until it falls. There's a satisfying crash at the bottom

Dialogue.Line: Let's get out of here.
No. No, hang on a minute. Somebody might have heard us.
There is no work party in shaft nine. Why?
The section is completed. The labour force is being assembled for clearing operations.
Work must proceed to schedule. There must be no delays.
All will be ready. The waste bucket in shaft nine is being lowered now.
I think it's all clear now.
Might as well take a chance. We can't stay here all night. What's happening?
We're going down!
Oh, dear. Ghastly. Well I must say this is a nice state of affairs. We've barely covered a mile and here we are hiding down the sewers again.
We're better to hide down here, Doctor, than be caught by those Robomen.
Tyler, did they see us?
Well, they were coming this way but they don't seem to know what they were going to do.
How many?
Just two of them. Listen, I couldn't get that cover on. We'd better get under shelter. Doctor, Susan.
You do realise, of course, we shall have to let them both come down before we decide to defend ourselves.
Well, we can take them one at a time.
Oh yes, just one. The other's bound to return and bring back reinforcements.
If we stick together long enough, I'll learn to do what you say the first time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Robomen peer down the manhole as David and Tyler check their ammunition. Then they both come down the ladder. Tyler's gun doesn't fire so he takes on the first Roboman hand to hand. Then David comes out of hiding.

Dialogue.Line: Move Tyler, move!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: David's shot misses and they both end up struggling with the Robomen. Susan runs to help David.

Dialogue.Line: No! No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor hits Tyler's adversary over the head with his new walking stick. Tyler finishes him off.

Dialogue.Line: Susan!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The second Roboman starts back up the ladder. Tyler picks up David's gun and shoots him

Dialogue.Line: Well, is everybody alright?
Yes.
Yes, Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tyler goes to shoot the other Roboman

Dialogue.Line: No, Tyler, no. I never take life. Only when my own is immediately threatened. Now then, let us make our way to this mine and then we shall know how to deal with these Daleks. Leave this creature to his own devices and salvation. Come along. You lead the way, my boy. Come along.
It's deserted, Jenny. With this storm coming, we'll be much better off inside.
Who's there? Who is it?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jenny and Barbara enter, and the girl screams

Dialogue.Line: What do you want?
We, we were looking for shelter.
Just the two of you? Tired, are you?
Yes. Yes, we are.
Barbara, I think we should be moving on.
Dogs'll catch you. Dogs in the forest.
Dogs?
Savage beasts. After the plague, they formed a pack. Where are you making for?
The mine. We have friends there. We're trying to find them.
Nobody gets away from there. You'll be caught yourselves.
You're lucky to have got this far. The patrols pass here.
Then how is it you're still free. They must know you're here?
Oh, they know all right. Yes, they know, but we can't harm them. Besides, we make clothes for the slave workers. We're more use to them doing that than we would be in the mine.
How do you manage? For food, I mean?
Oh, they give us some in return for the clothes. We're hungry most of the time though.
We have some food here. You're welcome to that.
Thank you, thank you. Get the table ready, child.
Yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The woman starts searching Barbara's rucksack

Dialogue.Line: More? Have you got any more in here? Oh yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara rescues the notebook and the woman pierces another can with a very large knife to check the contents

Dialogue.Line: In return you can sleep here for the night. You can make your bed out of this cloth. Come on, child. Come on. You'll be nice and comfortable there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: she goes and whispers to the girl

Dialogue.Line: Now, you go and take these and go (unintelligible) there's a good girl. Go on, then, there's a good girl.
I have to go out to deliver these clothes.
Your meal will be ready when you get back, child.
Go out in this weather?
They're waiting for her.
What about those dogs you talked about?
Oh, she'll follow the patrols.
I'll follow the patrols.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girl leaves

Dialogue.Line: She'll come to no harm. She's done it often enough. And when you 've done with your beds, shall you help me with the food?
Still no sign of the bottom.
No. How long do you think we've been going down now?
Must be nearly twenty minutes. It's getting warmer, isn't it?
Yes. Pressure's increasing too. My ears are popping.
I'd rather be dead than work down here.
Not a choice I'd like to face.
It's stopping. We must be near the bottom. Yes, look. Lights!
Let's get out of here, Larry, before this bucket tips up.
It's a bit of a drop, Ian.
Well, about twelve feet, that's all. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian jumps first. Larry is still in the bucket when it starts to go along a rail. He falls badly when he jumps

Dialogue.Line: Larry, you all right?
It's my kneecap. I caught it on the truck as I fell.
Put your weight on me. Stand up.
It's no good.
No? if you can't move, we'd better get under cover. It's too light here. We'll go over there. Now, put your weight on me. That's it. Slowly.
I went to London once. It seems years ago now. You know, is it still the same?
They've destroyed most of it.
Destroyed? Well I never. Oh, when I went it was beautiful. There was the moving pavements, and the shops, and the astronaut fair I went to and it was in the Chelsea heliport.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The girl returns and runs to the woman

Dialogue.Line: You will follow me, both of you. Do not try to escape or you will be exterminated. Move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jenny and Barbara leave

Dialogue.Line: Bread and oranges and sugar.
Oh, good, good. I knew they'd give us food if we told them. Oh, well. She'd have been captured anyway.
How're you feeling?
Better. I don't think I'll be able to walk.
Don't worry. We'll stay here for a while. You know, Larry, this mine doesn't make sense to me. Where's all the modern machinery?
The Daleks brought machinery from all over the world. All they seem to be shifting is rocks.
Yes. I suppose they could be processing it somewhere.
Who knows what the Daleks are up to? I told you what my brother Phil said, all they want is the magnetic core of Earth.
Yes, but why find it in such an old-fashioned way?
It's probably a clearance area. Perhaps we haven't found the main shaft yet.
You may be right at that. Larry, would you be all right if I went to have a look?
Yeah, sure.
Good man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian hears someone coming and hides with Larry behind some baskets. Robomen lead in a work party who start taking the baskets

Dialogue.Line: (spotting them) You'll have to move. They're clearing this whole section.
Move? Where to?
Well, lets join them. Take a basket, Larry.
(a Roboman) Halt!
Phil! It's my brother. Ian, it's my brother.
Too many in working party. Dalek Supreme Control recheck. Who are you?
Phil? Phil, it's Larry. Your brother Larry. Think, Phil! Remember me!
You are both runaways.
Angela. Your wife, Angela! I'll take you to her.
You must both be punished.
It's no good, Larry.
No, no! No, Ian!
Come on!
Ian, get clear. Run while you've got the chance! Run, Ian. Run.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Larry throttles Phil while Phil shoots Larry

Dialogue.Line: Run, Ian, run.
Larry.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They die, and the alarm goes off

Dialogue.Line: (behind next dialogue) Emergency! Emergency! Priority shaft nine. Close all exits! Emergency!

Right, get these bodies clear. Get them down the shafts. Shaft seven, shaft eight! I'll take care of that. (the gun) Someone tell them what's happened. Run, quick as you like. Get those bodies out of here. Hurry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian runs down a side passage
Susan adds some seasoning to a saucepan cooking on a camp fire. David sneaks up behind her and dangles a fish in front of her face. She screams.

Dialogue.Line: Some fresh fish! You want some fresh fish? I've got some!
David, you idiot. You idiot.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They have a little wrestling match on the grass

Dialogue.Line: Oh no, its not for me! I didn't want it! Not me!
Drop it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: David takes Susan's hand

Dialogue.Line: Your grandfather stood up to the journey fantastically well.
He's a pretty fantastic sort of man.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They kiss, barely

Dialogue.Line: Smells familiar round here.
Just in time for food.
Ah, yes, my dear.
Ah, we were just, er, well, I was just, er.
Quite, quite. I can see something's cooking.
What is that?
That's rabbit.
It's pretty primitive. It's the best I could do though.
Most useful.
Hot!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tyler wraps his sleeve around his hand to pick up the saucepan and sample the meal

Dialogue.Line: Hey, you've got a big piece there. Doctor, would you like some? Smells delicious.
Susan's a very good cook.
Yes. Tell me, Doctor.
Hmm?
Now that you've seen the Dalek base, what do you think?
Well it's quite obvious to me its the centre of their operations.
Centre?
Yes, quite. You know, you surprise me, Tyler. Why didn't you concentrate your efforts here?
We've been fighting the Daleks everywhere. Well, the fact that they started mining operations didn't seem all that important.
Yeah, well, we assumed that they were just digging for minerals, you know, something they could use to make
No, I think perhaps it might be the answer to the question as to why the Daleks are here.
But why, Doctor? Surely they've invaded us?

Oh no, it goes much deeper than that. You see, man, to them, is just a work machine. An insignificant specimen that is not worth invading. Absolutely useless. It doesn't matter to them whether you live or die.
Yeah, that's true enough.
Well, what are they digging for?
Well, at the moment, my boy, I'm not quite sure, but let us say something that this planet contains. Something that no planet has.
And you think if it was something on the surface, they'd have just collected it and gone?
Yes, quite, quite. Instead, there they are, burrowing like moles down and through the crust of the Earth.
But isn't that impossible? I mean, without causing an eruption, a huge earthquake no one could survive.
Not unless they know how to control the flow of living energy, hmm?
Is that what it is? They dare to tamper with the forces of creation?
Yes, they dare. And we have got to dare to stop them.
Grandfather?
Hmm?
It's getting cold. Look.
Keep moving.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian hides as a work party goes past, including Barbara and Jenny

Dialogue.Line: Move!
Barbara! (A little way on)
Fill these buckets. Hurry!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Baskets of rocks are emptied into a wagon on rails under the watch of a Dalek. Jenny can't lift the basket

Dialogue.Line: We're beaten, Barbara. We'll never get out of here. Never.
Don't be silly, Jenny. That's no way to talk. Look, we wanted to get to the mine and we're here.
Yes, but what can we do?
You can help me fill this basket again. We could try and find their main control room. I'm sure that's what the Doctor would do.
And then what will happen?
Oh, I don't know, Jenny, I don't know, but look, we can try! If we get there and fail, well, all they'll do is send us back here.
You. Take all buckets to the clearing section.
Fine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wells hands something to Jenny as he takes the basket, then heads down the passage to where he meets Ian

Dialogue.Line: Wells.
Ian, I told you to get out of here.
That's easier said than done. Wells, that tall girl in the blue sweater. I know her. Tell her I'm here.
Right, I'll try, but I've got to get rid if these first.
Yes, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Further on

Dialogue.Line: Anyway, they'll never let us anywhere near the control room.
Dortmun's notes!
What?
Jenny, I've still got Dortmun's notes!
And a lot of good they are.
No, no, you don't understand, Oh, I haven't got time to explain. Jenny, come with me.
Oh Barbara, do you know what you're doing?
Get back to work.
I have some important information. Rebels are planning a revolution against the Daleks.
There will be no revolution. The Daleks are masters of Earth.
But you don't understand. This is no ordinary uprising. They have scientists, men of learning working with them.
You are lying. It is a trick.
No, I have proof of what I say.
Proof? Let me see.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: She holds up the notes

Dialogue.Line: Details of the acid bomb used in the unprovoked attack on the London saucer landing area.
There's more. I know places where they're hiding.
Very well. Speak.
Well, it, it would be better if I spoke to someone in charge.
That is impossible. Tell me your story.
But it's very complex and detailed. You would have to act immediately on what I told you. I must speak to someone in authority.
The Black Dalek will see you, but if you are lying, you will be killed. Follow me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara and Jenny follow the Dalek

Dialogue.Line: Continue your work.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Along the passage

Dialogue.Line: Right, step into line and follow me.
We're too late. The Daleks have just taken her.
Pity. Oh well, there's an empty gallery behind us there. Lose yourself there.
Right.
Give me your report.
The main drills have penetrated the quartz strata. We are within four miles of the Earth's outer core.
When will the final breakthrough occur?
The slave parties are clearing the top of the fissure now.
What remains to be done?
Only to put into position the penetration explosive. The charge is in the fissure capsule now. When positioned, the charge will strike the fissure in the Earth's crust here.
The fissure will expand, the molten core be released.
We will then control the flow until all the gravitational and magnetic forces in the Earth's core are eliminated.
Excellent. I will now announce to the Dalek Earth force, completion of Project Degravitate in two hours time.
Attention.
Attention all units. Stand by for an announcement by the Supreme Controller.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian hides in a capsule

Dialogue.Line: This is the Supreme Controller. Our mission to Earth is nearly completed. We were sent here to remove the core of this planet.
Once the core is removed, we can replace it with a power system that will enable us to pilot the planet anywhere in the universe.
All that remains is to put into position the penetration explosive. Daleks controlling device will now report.
We are ready.
Arm the device.
Device now armed.
Set capsule in motion.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The other half of the capsule casing moves forward, trapping Ian inside

Dialogue.Line: Hatch over control to closed position. Motor running.
Capsule moving.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the capsule slides down its guide rails, Ian is busy inside, fiddling with wires. He pulls some out and the capsule stops. So he continues to pull wires and twist them together
A team of Robomen are pulling on the rope attached to the top of the capsule

Dialogue.Line: Pull. Pull. Pull.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As the capsule ascends and Ian messes with the wires, a trap door opens by his feet.

Dialogue.Line: Pull. Pull. Pull.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian climbs down the rope out of the capsule

Dialogue.Line: Capsule now arrived at sub station.
Ascertain extent of breakdown and then
Man has been seen leaving capsule.
Exterminate him! Exterminate him! Exterminate him!
Stay where you are!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Dalek fires at the rope, which snaps and Ian slides down to a door at the top of the fissure proper. He is out cold

Dialogue.Line: We must be getting near their control room, Barbara. What do you want me to do?
Move.
Try to find the main control panel. Do as much damage as you can. I'll try and keep them occupied.
Silence. You will only speak when you are ordered to do so.
Dalek reports human fallen down bomb shaft. Capsule is being repaired.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara and Jenny enter

Dialogue.Line: Wait here.
Every error must be corrected. The penetration explosive must strike the fissure correctly if we are to extract the molten core. Have all work tasks been completed?
They have.
Then arrange for the extermination of all human beings.
Kill, kill, kill, kill, kill!
The final solution! Clear up this planet!
Alter the command frequencies to aural control to all Robomen. They are to herd humans down to the lower galleries.
Immediately. Testing aural control. Testing aural control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A light flashes on a Roboman's helmet

Dialogue.Line: Testing aural control. Testing aural control.
Did you see that, Jenny? That's the way they control the Robomen.
Herd all humans to galleries to nine, ten and fifteen.
Perhaps we could put it out of action?
We could do better than that, we could give it new orders. Tell them to turn on the Daleks.
Yes! That's a great idea.
They are the prisoners that reported the imminent revolt.
Speak!
(reading Dortmun's notes.) This bomb is the one with which
We are not interested in the bomb. Give your information!
Right. This revolt is timed to start almost immediately. As in the case of the Indian mutiny, which I am sure
Indian mutiny? We are the masters of India!
I was talking about Red Indians in disguise! The plan will run parallel with the Boston Tea Party. Naturally, you already have information about this.
Wait! Why have I not been informed of this?
There has been no information.

Good! That means the first part of the plan is a success. Now, I warn you, General Lee and the four, the fifth cavalry are already forming up to attack from the north side of the crater. The second wave, Hannibal's forces, will of course come in from the Southern Alps. The third wave
Attention! Attention! Mobilise defence forces!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara dashes to the Robomen control panel

Dialogue.Line: Robomen, this order cannot be countermanded. You must
Take them! They are lying! Take them! Take them! Take them!
I will arrange for their extermination.
No. Secure them. They will be killed in the explosion. The countdown must proceed to schedule.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara and Jenny are fastened by collars to a pillar.

Dialogue.Line: Sorry, Jenny.
What for? It was a marvellous attempt and it nearly worked too.
Yes, it didn't and we won't get a second try. Look. That must be the bomb shaft.
Have you ever seen anything like that mine, Doctor?
I certainly have not. Ah, good! There seems to be a way down there.
I still say its madness.
Yes, well lets have a closer look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor peers down through binoculars

Dialogue.Line: Yes, Doctor?
How many bombs have you got left?
Er, I've got three, I think.
Yes, well that should be enough. Now, you see that mast over there?
(through binoculars) Yes.
And the cable behind it?
Yes.
Well, I want you and Susan to walk around the lip of the crater and sever it. Use the bombs. Detonate with your revolver, right?
Right, Doctor.
Off you go, and don't stop to pick daises on the way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: David and Susan leave.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think they'll run into any trouble.
And what about us?
That'll be harder to guarantee. Come along. Get down.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian comes round, and opens a circular door in a stone wall. A Roboman enters the room on the other side so Ian closes it again

Dialogue.Line: As soon as the repairs to the capsule are complete, the explosive device will be released into the bowels of this planet.
Sounds as though they're almost ready.
Attention all Daleks. Our saucers are hovering above the mine area. Notice to board saucers will be given shortly.
Now, I've neutralised the warning system.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A door opens.

Dialogue.Line: Shall we go in?
I'll say one thing, Doc. Life's never dull with you around.
Thank you, but don't call me Doc, I prefer Doctor. Do you mind?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ian opens the small door again. The room contains small tree trunks so he uses some to block what will be the passage of the capsule

Dialogue.Line: The work on the capsule is complete. The device is ready.
Good. We shall have one hour to leave when the device is fired. Am firing now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The capsule slides down its guide rails and stops when it hits Ian's barrier

Dialogue.Line: The explosive device is on its way to the centre of the Earth. We shall go the edge of the mine workings and be picked up by the saucers.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Tyler hide as the Black Dalek leads the others away

Dialogue.Line: That was a close one.
Apparently things are on the move.
Well, they didn't bother to kill us. I suppose the explosion will take care of that.
It's no good, Barbara. I can't move mine!
Listen. I think the Daleks are coming back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor and Tyler enter

Dialogue.Line: My dear Barbara!
Doctor!
The magnet! The magnet, quickly!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tyler grabs it

Dialogue.Line: Is Chesterton with you? Never mind.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The women are released

Dialogue.Line: We must begin our action before the Daleks get back.
I don't think they will be coming back. They activated one of their bombs. They intend to blow a hole through the centre of the Earth.
But why?
They're trying to pilot the Earth right out of its orbit. The bomb's due to go off in half an hour's time.
Well, we must prevent this, Barbara. If they succeed, it will the mean that they'll upset the entire constellation. We've got to prevent it!
But how?
By keeping the Daleks here. Keep your eyes skinned on the door.
All right.
Now, I wonder. Can I do anything with this scanner?
There's Susan!
Oh yes! Susan and David. Now, they're trying to fracture the outer cable ring.
Well what will that do?
Well, if it's possible, you see, we might be able to immobilise the Daleks.
Scanner frequencies have been changed in Central control.
The prisoners must have escaped! Deal with them.
The radio circuit's still working.
Hurry, Susan, hurry!
There's nothing we can do, my dear. Just watch and wait. We can't contact them from here.
Two zero reporting.
A Dalek's coming.
Will exterminate them at zero range.
It's nearly here. (On the scanner, David and Susan do their job)
Thermostat reading too high! Heat increase intolerable! Heat increase complete! Power loss complete! Argh!
You took a chance.
A chance? Yes.
Can you stop the bomb, Doctor?
Not now, Barbara. We don't know how long this little trick of ours will hold the Daleks. We may have to find something else.
Well, look. That thing over there controls the Robomen. We discovered that earlier. Er, maybe we could give it new orders?
Yes! That's brilliant, my dear! Good. Carry on.
(as a Dalek) Robomen, this is your last order. Obey it and no other.
Turn on the Daleks, turn on the Daleks, kill the Daleks, do you hear?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: And they do
Wells and a group arrive and take away the dead Dalek. Ian bursts in

Dialogue.Line: Barbara!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hug

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
My dear boy, where did you spring from?
Well, I was trying to get out of the mine and suddenly the Robomen turned on the Daleks! Well, you know the rest.
Well, the people are fighting back at last!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The people and Robomen are running out of the mine entrance

Dialogue.Line: That must be where I jammed it, so that must be where it will explode.
But look, it's going to go off in ten minutes time.
I don't think their device will succeed in that position. But still, it will be a gigantic explosion.
Then we ought to get as many people out of this area as we possibly can.
Yes, I quite agree.
We'll be safe outside the valley.
And we must all meet back on the cliff, we were before. Now hurry up, all of you.
The explosion will take place any second. Keep right down, all of you!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: KaBOOM! and the magma wells up from the mine. A mushroom cloud ascends

Dialogue.Line: The saucers were caught in the upward thrust of that explosion.
Do you think any Daleks escaped?
In that, my dear? Impossible. There's something new for you, Tyler. A volcanic eruption in England.
It's unbelievable.
Yes, it's unbelievable.
It's over.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wells helps clear the last timber from a very battered Tardis

Dialogue.Line: Well, at least the firebombs didn't destroy everything. Pity Dortmun couldn't be here. Dortmun and people like him.
Yes, and it's to them that you must dedicate your next task, the rebuilding of the Earth. And I'm sure you're going to make a great success of it.
You sound as if you're leaving.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Westminster chimes sound

Dialogue.Line: Listen.
Just the beginning. Just the beginning. All alone, eh, Susan, hmm?
I was thinking.
Yes, I afraid we've had so little time for that sort of thing lately.
It would be nice if we
I, er, well, I'm sorry, Susan.
It wasn't important. What were you going to, Ow!
Oh my dear Susan, you're hurt.
Oh, it's not me, it's this shoe of mine. Look, it's worn right out.
Oh, dear, dear, dear.
It must have been that journey back from the mine.
Dear, dear, dear, I shall have to mend this, shan't I now?
Oh, don't worry, Grandfather.
Oh, no, no, no, no, no worry, my child, no. When I've finished with this, it will look as good as new.
Really, it's not worth it. I've got dozens of other pairs.
Yes. Hmm.
I'd better clear out my cupboard. It's in a dreadful muddle.

Yes, you little monkey. You know, since you've been away from that school, you seem to have got yourself thoroughly disorganised, haven't you? Yes, you need taking in hand. Well, I, er, I think I must check up on the ship, if you don't mind.
Won't be long. (The Doctor watches Susan go over to David, then goes into the Tardis)
What are your plans, David?
Me? Oh, I'll join a group that work the land. More than anything, I want to see things grow again. I want to be a part of it.
It's a nice idea. Do you come from the country?
Yes. My family have always been associated with the land.
Oh, er, where do they live?
Well, they live a long way from here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Barbara hauls Ian away

Dialogue.Line: Well can't stand here talking all day. See me before you go, David.
I will Tyler. I will.
Goodbye, Tyler.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Tyler's gone

Dialogue.Line: Goodbye.
Susan?
Yes, David?
Please stay. Please stay here with me.
I can't stay, David. I don't belong to this time.
But I love you, Susan, and I want you to marry me.
You see, David. Grandfather's old now. He needs me. Oh, don't make me choose between you and him, please!

But you told me! You said that you'd never known the security of living in one place and one time. Look, you said it was something that you always longed for. Well, I'm giving you that, Susan. I'm giving you a place, a time, an identity.
No, David! (crying) I've lost my shoe. Oh David, I do love you! I do, I do, I do!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Inside the Tardis, the Doctor closes the doors

Dialogue.Line: Grandfather!
Listen, Susan, please. I've double-locked the doors. You can't get in. Now move back, child, where I can see you.
During all the years, I've been taking care of you, you in return have been taking care of me.
Oh, Grandfather, I belong with you!
Not any longer, Susan. You're still my grandchild and always will be, but now, you're a woman too.
I want you to belong somewhere, to have roots of your own. With David, you'll be able to find those roots and live normally like any woman should do.

Believe me, my dear, your future lies with David, and not with a silly old buffer like me. One day, I shall come back. Yes, I shall come back. Until then, there must be no regrets, no tears, no anxieties. Just go forward in all your beliefs, and prove to me that I am not mistaken in mine. Goodbye, Susan, goodbye, my dear.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis dematerialises. Susan, with only one shoe, walks where it had stood

Dialogue.Line: Susan? Susan? He knew. He knew you could never leave him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Susan looks at her Tardis key, then drops it on the ground, and they slowly walk off hand in hand
